summary: Email correspondence between prosecutors in the Ghislaine Maxwell case and Dr. Gail Goodman, a psychology professor and expert on memory, regarding her potential consultation and testimony as an expert witness for the prosecution. The emails discuss scheduling calls and include Dr. Goodman's background information and research on memory, particularly regarding child sexual abuse.

persons.name: Gail Goodman
persons.role: Distinguished Professor of Psychology, potential expert witness
persons.context: A psychology professor at UC Davis with expertise in memory, especially regarding child sexual abuse, being contacted by prosecutors to potentially consult and testify in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case 'United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell' mentioned as the subject of the trial for which Dr. Goodman is being contacted as a potential expert witness.

connections.description: Dr. Goodman is being contacted by prosecutors to potentially provide expert testimony in the criminal trial against Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell trial begins
events.description: The criminal trial of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell is scheduled to begin.

keyFacts: Prosecutors in the Ghislaine Maxwell case contacted Dr. Gail Goodman, an expert on memory and child sexual abuse, to potentially serve as an expert witness for the prosecution.
Dr. Goodman's research focuses on long-term memory for child sexual abuse experiences, and she has testified in federal court previously, but only for the prosecution.

The emails discuss the 'misinformation effect' on memory, with Dr. Goodman noting that under certain conditions, misinformation can actually make memory more accurate for personally significant events.
The trial of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell was scheduled to begin on November 29, 2021.
Dr. Goodman is a Distinguished Professor and Director of the Center for Public Policy Research in the Department of Psychology at UC Davis.
